content:
I received an answer from claude help: You're experiencing a known issue! There's currently an active incident affecting conversation compaction that we identified today. The automatic summarization feature isn't working properly right now, which explains why your long conversations aren't being compacted as expected.
This could definitely be causing the excessive token consumption you mentioned. Normally, when conversations approach the context window limit, Claude automatically summarizes earlier messages to continue seamlessly without counting against your usage limits. When this feature isn't working, you're essentially "re-reading" the entire conversation history with each new message, which uses up your tokens much faster.
We've identified the root cause and are implementing a fix. You can track the progress at: https://stspg.io/30s41gfl3zq4
In the meantime, you can manually manage this by starting new conversations for different topics or using the /compact command if you're using Claude Code to reduce token usage.
# Compaction is having issues

content:
GPT-5.2 Ã— Claude Opus 4.5 â€” Autonomous Synchronization in Practice
Today I achieved what turned out to be the hardest part:
 making two different models work in true synchronization, without stalling and without human intervention.
I built a system where GPT-5.2 and Claude Opus 4.5 operate in complementary roles under an autonomous coordinator:
â€¢ GPT-5.2 as the Tech Lead: planning, validating, supervising, and making decisions.
 â€¢ Claude Opus 4.5 as the Senior Engineer: executing, coding, iterating, and resolving.
 â€¢ A state-machine-driven orchestrator that guarantees continuity, detects stalls, and reactivates the flow when progress stops.
The challenge was not getting â€œgood answers.â€
 The challenge was ensuring the system never stops â€” knowing when to wait, when to ask, and when to continue on its own.
That required:
â€“ State synchronization
 â€“ Explicit transition rules
 â€“ Automatic inactivity detection
 â€“ Autonomous handling of CLI questions
 â€“ Retries, timeouts, and error recovery
 â€“ Continuous execution with no human in the loop
In practice, two frontier models collaborating in a stable, self-regulated way to complete end-to-end tasks.
This is where AI stops being an assistant
 and starts behaving like a self-governing system.

content:
They specify their setup:
> For Claude Code, we follow the default recommendation of running the agent in headless mode and using Opus 4.5 as the primary model:
> --model=opus --allowedTools="Bash,Read" --permission-mode acceptEdits --output-format stream-json --verbose. This resulted in a mixed execution pattern where Opus 4.5 handles core reasoning and Haiku 4.5 is delegated auxiliary tasks. Across trajectories, ~30% of steps originate from Haiku, with the remaining majority from Opus 4.5. We use version 2.0.62 of Claude Code. In rare instances (1â€“2 out of 47 tasks), Claude Code attempts to use prohibited tools like WebFetch or user approval, resulting in timeouts and task failure.
